<description type="note">Preliminaries and editorial matter including introduction and glossary omitted.<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:<lb/>Source texts incomplete</description>
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.

XXXIII. THE TYLLEMAKERS. The second Trial before Pilate continued; the Judgment of Jesus. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Jesus. Pilatus. Anna. Cayphas. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 Milites. Preco (Beadle or Porter). Barabbas.]

[Scene, Pilate's Hall.] 1. Pil. Lordynges, Ã¾at are lymett to Ã¾e lare of my liaunce, ?e schappely schalkes and schene for to schawe, I charge ?ou as ?our chiftan Ã¾at ?e chatt for no chaunce, But loke to youre lord here, and lere at my lawe. As a duke I may dampne ?ou and drawe, Many bernys bolde are aboute me, And what knyght or knave I may knawe Ãat list no?t as a lord for to lowte me, I sall lere hym In the deueles name, Ã¾at dastard, to dowte me. ?a, who werkis any werkes with-oute me, I sall charge hym in chynes to chere hym. 2. Tharfore ?e lusty ledes, with-in Ã¾is lenght lapped, Do stynte of ?oure stalkyng and of stoutnes be stalland, What traytoures his tong with tales has trapped, That fende for his flateryng full foull sall be falland. What broll ouere brathely is bralland, Or vnsoftely will sege in Ã¾er sales, Ãat cayteffe Ã¾us carpand and calland As a boy sall be broght vn-to bales. Ãerfore Talkes not nor trete not of tales, For Ã¾at gome Ã¾at gyrnes or gales, I myself sall hym hurte full sore. 3. An. ?e sall sytt hym full sore, what sege will assay ?ou, If he like not youre lordshippe, Ã¾at ladde, sall ?e lere hym, As a pereles prince full prestly to pay ?ou, Or as a derworth duke with dyntes sall ?e dere hym. Cay. ?aa, in faythe ?e haue force for to fere hym, Thurgh youre manhede and myght bes he marred, No chyualrus chiftan may chere hym, Fro that churll with charge ?e haue charred [and chasted?] Cay. In pynyng payne bees he parred, An. ?aa, and with schath of skelpys yll scarred Fro tyme Ã¾at youre tene he haue tasted. 4. Now certes, as me semes, who so sadly has soght ?ou, Youre praysyng is prophetable, ?e prelates of pees, Gramercy, ?oure goode worde, and vngayne sall it no?t you, That ?e will say the sothe and for no sege cese. Cay. Elles were it pite we appered in Ã¾is prees, But consayue how ?oure knyghtes ere command. An. ?a, my lord, Ã¾at leve ?e no lese I can telle you, ?ou tydes sum tythandis ful sadde. Pil. Se, they bring ?oone brolle in a bande; We sall here nowe, hastely at hand, What vnhappe before Herowde he had. 5. i Mil. Hayll! louelyest lorde Ã¾at euere lawe led ?itt, Hayll! semelyest vndre on euere ilka syde, Hayll! stateliest on stede in strenghe Ã¾at is sted ?itt, Hayll! liberall, hayll! lusty to lordes allied. Pil. Welcome, what tydandis Ã¾is tyde, Late no langgage lightly nowe lette ?ou. ii Mil. Sir Herowde, sir, it is not to hyde, As his gud frende grathely he grete yowe for euere, In what manere Ã¾at euere he mete ?ou, By hym-selfe full sone wille he sette you, And sais Ã¾at ?e sall not disseuer. 6. Pil. I thanke hym full thraly, and sir, I saie hym Ã¾e same, But what meruelous materes dyd Ã¾is myron Ã¾er mell? i Mil. For all Ã¾e lordis langage his lipps, sir, wer lame, For any spirringes in Ã¾at space no speche walde he spell. Bot domme as a dore gon he dwell, Ãus no faute in hym gon he fynde, For his dedis to deme hym to qwell, Nor in bandis hym brathely to bynde, and Ã¾us He sente hym to youre self, and assynde Ãat we, youre knyghtis, suld be clenly enclyned, And tyte with hym to you to trus. 7. Pil. Syrs, herkens! here ?e not what we haue oppon hand, Loo, howe Ã¾ere knyghtes carpe Ã¾at to Ã¾e kyng cared! Syr Herowde, Ã¾ai say no faute in me fand, He fest me to his frenschippe, so frendly he fared. More-over sirs, he spake, and noght spared, Full gentilly to Jesu Ã¾is iewe, And sithen to ther knyghtis declared How fawtes in hym fande he but fewe To dye, He taste hym, I telle ?ou for trewe, For to dere hym he demed vndewe, And sirs, Ã¾e sothly saie I. 8. Cai. Sir Pilate oure prince, we prelatis nowe pray ?ou, Sen Herowde fraysted no ferÃ¾er Ã¾is faitour to slaye, Resayue in ?our sall Ã¾er sawes Ã¾at I saie you, Late bryng hym to barre, and at his berde sall we baye. An. ?a, for and he wende Ã¾us by wiles away, I wate wele he wirke will vs wondre, Oure men?e he marres Ã¾at he may, With his seggynges he settes Ã¾am in sondre, With synne. With his blure he bredis mekill blondre; Whills ?e haue hym, nowe haldes hym vndir, We sall wery hym away yf he wynne. 9. Cay. Sir, no tyme is to tarie Ã¾is traytour to taste, Agayne Sir Cesar hym selfe he segges and saies, All Ã¾e wightis in this world wirkis in waste, Ãat takis hym any tribute; Ã¾us his teching outrayes. ?itt forther he feynes slik affraies, And sais Ã¾at hym self is God son; And sir, oure lawe leggis and layes In what faytour falsed is fon Suld be slayne. Pil. For no schame hym to shende will we shon. An. Sir, witnesse of Ã¾is wanes may be wonne, Ãat will tell Ã¾is with-owten any trayne. 10. Cayp. I can reken a rable of renkes full right, Of perte men in prese fro this place ar I pas, Ãat will witnesse, I warande, Ã¾e wordis of Ã¾is wight, How wikkidly wrought Ã¾at Ã¾is wrecche has; Simon, ?arus, and Judas, Datan and Gamaliell, Neptalim, Leui, and Lucas, And Amys Ã¾is maters can mell to-githere; Ãer tales for trewe can they telle, Of this faytour Ã¾at false is and felle, And in legyng of lawes ful lithre. 11. Pil. ?a, tussch! for youre tales, Ã¾ai touche not entente, Ãer witnesse I warande Ã¾at to witnesse ?e wage, Some hatred in ther hartis agaynes hym haue hent, And purpose be this processe to putt down Ã¾is page. Caip. Sir, in faith vs fallith not to fage, Ãai are t[r]yst men and true Ã¾at we telle ?ou, Pil. Youre swering, seris, swiftely ?e swage, And no more in this maters ye mell ?ou, I charge. An. Sir, dispise not Ã¾is speche Ã¾at we spell you, Pil. If ?e feyne slike frawdis, I sall felle ?ou, For me likis noght youre langage so large. 12. Cai. Oure langage is to large, but ?oure lordshipp releue vs, ?itt we both beseke you, late brynge hym to barre, What poyntes Ã¾at we putte forth, latt your presence appreue vs, ?e sall here how Ã¾is harlott heldes out of herre. Pil. ?a, butt be wise, witty, and warre. An. ?is, sir, drede ?ou no?t for no thyng we doute hym. Fecche hym, he is noght right ferre, Do bedell, buske Ã¾e abowte hym. Preco. I am fayne, My lorde, for to lede hym or lowte hym, Vncleth hym, clappe hym, and clowte hym, If ?e bid me, I am buxhome and bayne. [Goes to the soldiers. 13. Knyghtis, ?e er commaundid with Ã¾is caityf to care, And bryng hym to barre, and so my lord badd. i Mil. Is Ã¾is thy messege? [PrÃ¦co] ?a, sir. [i Mil.] Ãan moue Ã¾e no mare, For we ar light for to leppe and lede forthe Ã¾e ladd. ii Mil. [To Jesus.] Do steppe furth, in striffe ert Ã¾ou stadde, I vphalde full euyll has Ã¾e happed. i Mil. O man, thy mynde is full madde, In oure clukis to be clowted and clapped, And closed. ii Mil. Ãou bes lassched, lusschyd, and lapped. i Mil. ?a, rowted, russhed, and rapped, Ãus thy named with noye sall be noysed. 14. ii Mil. [To Pilate.] Loo, this sege her, my souerayne, Ã¾at ?e for-sente. Pil. Wele, stirre no?t fro Ã¾at stede, but stande stille Ã¾are; Bot he schappe som shrewdnesse, with shame bese he shente, And I will frayst in faith, to frayne of hir fare. Caip. [Starting.] We, outte! stande may I no?t, so I stare. An. ?a, harrowe, of this traytour with tene. Pil. Say, renkes, what rewth gars you rare? Er ye woode, or wittles I wene, What eyles ?ou? Caip. Out! slike a sight suld be sene. An. ?a! allas, conquered ar we clene. Pil. We! ere ?e fonde, or youre force fayles ?ou? 15. Cai. A! sir, saugh ?e no?t Ã¾is sight, how Ã¾at Ã¾er schaftes schuke, And the? baneres to this brothell Ã¾ai bowde all on brede? An. ?a, ther cursed knyghtes by crafte lete them croke, To worshippe Ã¾is warlowe vnworthy in wede. Pil. Was it dewly done, Ã¾us in dede? Caip. ?a, ?a, sir, oure selfe we it sawe. Pil. We! spitte on them, ill mott Ã¾ai spede! Say, dastard, Ã¾e deuyll mote ?ou drawe, How dar ?e Ãer baners on brede Ã¾at her blawe, Lat lowte to Ã¾is lurdan so lawe? O faytouris, with falshed how fare ?e? 16. iii Mil. We beseke you and tho seniouris beside ?ou, sir, sitte, With none of oure gouernaunce to be greuous and gryll, For it lay not in oure lott Ã¾er launces to lett, And Ã¾is werke Ã¾at we haue wrought it was not oure will. Pil. Ãou lise, harstow, lurdan? full ille, Wele Ã¾ou watte if Ã¾Ã³u witnes it walde. iv Mil. Sir, oure strengh myght no?t stabill Ã¾am stille, They hilded for ought we couthe halde, Oure vnwittyng. v Mil. For all oure fors, in faith, did Ã¾ai folde, As Ã¾is warlowe worschippe Ã¾ai wolde; And vs semid, forsoth, it vnsittyng. 17. Cai. A! vnfrendly faytours, full fals is youre fable, Ãis segge with his suttelte to his seett haÃ¾ you sesid. vi Mil. ?e may say what you semes, sir, bot Ã¾er standerdes to stabill What freyke hym enforces full foull sall he be fesid. An. Be Ã¾e deuyllis nese, ?e ar doggydly diseasid, A! henne-harte! ill happe mot ?ou hente. Pil. For a whapp so he whyned and whesid And ?itt no lasshe to Ã¾e lurdan was lente, foul fall ?ou! iii Mil. Sir, i-wisse no wiles we haue wente, Shamefully ?ou satt to be shente, Here combred caystiffes, I call ?ou! 18. iv Mil. Sen ?ou lykis not, my lord, oure langage to leve, Latte bryng the biggest men Ã¾at abides in Ã¾is land, Propirly in youre presence Ã¾er pouste to preve, Be-holde Ã¾at they helde nott fro Ã¾ei haue Ã¾aim in hand. Pil. Now ?e er ferdest Ã¾at euere I fand, Fy on youre faynte hertis in feere, Stir Ã¾e, no langer Ã¾ou stande, Ãou bedell, Ã¾is bodworde Ã¾ou bere Thurgh Ã¾is towne;â Ãe wyghtest men vn-to were, And Ã¾e strangest Ã¾er standerdis to stere, Hider blithely bid Ã¾am be bowne. 19. Preco. My souerayne full sone sall be serued youre sawe, I sall bryng to Ã¾er baneres right bigg men and strange, A company of keuellis in this contre I knawe That grete ere and grill, to Ã¾e gomes will I gange. [Goes to two soldiers. Say, ye ledis botht lusty and lange, ?e most passe to sir Pilate a pace. i Mil. If we wirke not his wille it wer wrang, We are redy to renne on a race, And rayke. Preco. Then tarie not, but tryne on a trace, And folow me fast to his face. ii Mil. Do lede vs, vs lykes wele Ã¾is lake. [The Beadle returns with them to Pilate. 20. Pre. Lorde, here are Ã¾e biggest bernes Ã¾at bildis in Ã¾is burgh, Most stately and strange if with strenght Ã¾ai be streyned, Leve me, sir, I lie not, to loke Ã¾is lande thurgh, Ãai er myghtiest men with manhode demened. Pil. Wate Ã¾ou wele, or ellis has Ã¾ou wenyd. Pre. Sir, I wate wele, withoute wordis moo. Caip. In thy tale be not taynted nor tenyd. Pre. We! nay sir, why shuld I be soo? Pil. Wele Ã¾an, We sall frayst er they founde vs fer fro, To what game Ã¾ai be-gynne for to go, Sir Cayphas, declare Ã¾am ?e can. 21. Caip. ?e lusty ledis, nowe lith to my lare, Schappe ?ou to Ã¾er schaftis Ã¾at so schenely her schyne, If ?ou barnes bowe Ã¾e brede of an hare, Platly ?e be putte to perpetuell pyne. i Mil. I sall holde Ã¾is as even as a lyne. An. Who so schakis, with schames he shendes. ii Mil. I certayne, I saie as for myne, Whan it sattles or sadly discendis Whare I stande, When it wryngis or wronge it wendis, Outher bristis, barkis, or bendes,â Hardly lat hakke of myn hande! 22. Pil. Sirs, waites to Ã¾er wightis Ã¾at no wiles be wrought, Ãai are burely and brode, Ã¾are bost haue Ã¾ai blowen. An. To neven of Ã¾at nowe, sir, it nedis right noght, For who curstely hym quytes, he sone sall be knawen. Cay. ?a, Ã¾at dastard to dede sall be drawen, Who so fautis, he fouly sall falle. Pil. Nowe knyghtis, sen Ã¾e cokkis has crowen, Haue hym hense with hast fra this halle His wayes; Do stiffely steppe on Ã¾is stalle, Make a crye, and cautely Ã¾ou call, Euene like as sir Annay Ã¾e sais. 23. An. Jesu! Ã¾ou rewe of gentill Jacob kynne, Ãou nerthrist of Nazareth, now neuend is Ã¾i name, Alle creatures Ã¾e accuses, we commaunde Ã¾e comme in, And aunswer to Ã¾in enemys, deffende now thy fame. Et Preco, semper post Annam, recitabit, Judicatur Jesus. [The banners bow, and Pilate rises. Cay. We! out, we are shente alle for shame, Ãis is wrasted all wrange, as I wene. An. For all Ã¾er boste, ?one boyes are to blame. Pil. Slike a sight was neuere ?it sene! Come sytt; My comforth was caught fro me clene, I vpstritt! I me myght no?t abstene To wirschip hym in wark and in witte. 24. Cay. Ãer-of meruayled we mekill what moued ?ou in mynde, In reuerence of Ã¾is ribald so rudely to ryse. Pil. I was past all my powre, Ã¾ogh I payned me and pynd, I wrought not as I wolde in no maner of wise. Bot syrs, my spech wele aspise, Wightly his wayes late hym wende, Ãus my dome will dewly deuyse, For I am ferde hym in faith to offende, In sightes. An. Ãan oure lawe were laght till an ende To his tales if ?e treuly attende; He enchaunted & charmed oure knyghtis. 25. Cay. Be his sorcery, sir, youre selfe Ã¾e soth sawe, He charmes oure chyualers & with myscheffe enchaunted, To reuerence hym ryally we rase all on rowe, Doutles we endure not of Ã¾is dastard be daunted. Pil. Why, what harmes has Ã¾is hatell here haunted? I kenne to co[n]vyk hym no cause. An. To all gomes he God son hym graunted, And liste not to leve on oure lawes. Pil. [To Jesus.] Say, man Consayues Ã¾ou no?t what comberous clause Ãat Ã¾is clargye accusyng Ã¾e knawse? Speke, and excuse Ã¾e if Ã¾ou can. 26. Jesus. Euery man has a mouthe Ã¾at made is on molde, In wele and in woo to welde at his will, If he gouerne it gudly like as God wolde, For his spirituale speche hym [thar] not to spill. And what gome so gouerne it ill, Full vnhendly and ill sall he happe, Of ilk tale Ã¾ou talkis vs vntill, Ãou accounte sall, Ã¾ou can not escappe. Pil. Sirs myne, ?e foune in faithe all ?e frappe, For in Ã¾is lede no lese can I lappe, Nor no poynte to putt hym to pyne. 27. Cai. With-oute cause, sir, we come not Ã¾is carle to accuse hym, And Ã¾at will we ?e witt, as wele is worthy. Pil. Now I recorde wele Ã¾e right, ?e will no raÃ¾ere refuse hym, To he be dreuen to his dede and demed to dye; But takes hym vn-to you forthy, And like as youre lawe will you lere, Deme ?e his body to abye. An. O! sir Pilate, with-outen any pere, Do way, ?e wate wele with-outen any were, Vs falles not, nor oure felowes in feere To slo noman, youre self Ã¾e soth say. 28. Pil. Why suld I deme to dede Ã¾an with-oute deseruyng in dede? But I haue herde al haly why in hertes ?e hym hate, He is fautles in faith, and so god mote me spede, I graunte hym my gud will to gang on his gate. Cai. Nought so, sir, for wele ?e it wate, To be kyng he claymeth with croune, And who so stoutely will steppe to Ã¾at state, ?e suld deme, sir, to be dong doune And dede. Pil. Sir, trulye Ã¾at touched to tresoune, And or I remewe, he rewe sall Ã¾at reasoune, And or I stalke or stirre fro Ã¾is stede. 29. Sir knyghtis Ã¾at ar comly, take Ã¾is caystiff in keping, Skelpe hym with scourges and with skathes hym scorne, Wrayste and wryng hym to, for wo to he be wepyng, And Ã¾an bryng hym before vs as he was be-forne. i Mil. He may banne Ã¾e tyme he was borne; Sone sall he be serued as ?e saide vs. An. Do wappe of his wedis Ã¾at are worne. ii Mil. All redy sir, we haue arayde vs, Haue done. To Ã¾is broll late vs buske vs and brayde vs, As sir Pilate has propirly prayde vs. iii Mil. We sall sette to hym sadly sone. [They take Jesus to another part of the Hall. 30. iv Mil. Late vs gete of his gere, God giffe hym ille grace. i Mil. Ãai ere tytt of tite, lo! take Ã¾er his trasshes. iii Mil. Nowe knytte hym in Ã¾is corde. ii Mil. I am caut in Ã¾is case. iv Mil. He is bun faste, nowe bete on with bittir brasshis. i Mil. Go on, lepis, har ?e, lordyngis, with lasshes, And enforce we Ã¾is faitour to flay hym. ii Mil. Late vs driffe to hym derfly with dasshes, Alle rede with oure rowtes we aray hym And rente hym. iii Mil. For my parte I am prest for to pay hym. iv Mil. ?a, sende hym sorow, assaye hym. i Mil. Take hym Ã¾at I haue tome for to tente hym. 31. ii Mil. Swyng to this swyre, to swiftely he swete. iii Mil. Swete may Ã¾is swayne for sweght of our swappes! iv Mil. Russhe on this rebald and hym rathely rehete! i Mil. Rehete hym I rede you with rowtes and rappes! ii Mil. For all oure noy, Ã¾is nygard he nappes. iii Mil. We sall wakken hym with wynde of oure whippes. iv Mil. Nowe flynge to Ã¾is flaterer with flappes. i Mil. I sall hertely hitte on his hippes and haunch. ii Mil. Fra oure skelpes not scatheles he skyppes. iii Mil. ?itt hym list not lyft vp his lippis, And pray vs to haue pety on his paunch. 32. iv Mil. To haue petie of his paunche he propheres no prayer. i Mil. Lorde, how likis thou Ã¾is lake and Ã¾is lare Ã¾at we lere ?ou? ii Mil. Lo, I pull at his pilche, I am prowd payer. iii Mil. Thus youre cloke sall we cloute to clence you and clere ?ou. iv Mil. I am straunge in striffe for to stere ?ou. i Mil. Ãus with choppes Ã¾is churll sall we chastye. ii Mil. I trowe with Ã¾is trace we sall tere you. iii Mil. All Ã¾in vntrew techyngis Ã¾us taste I, Ã¾ou tarand. iv Mil. I hope I be hardy and hasty. i Mil. I wate wele my wepon not wast I. ii Mil. He swounes or sweltes, I swarand. 33. iii Mil. Late vs louse hym lightyly, do lay on your handes. iv Mil. ?a, for and he dye for this dede, vndone ere we all. i Mil. Nowe vnboune is Ã¾is broll, and vnbraced his bandes. ii Mil. O fule, how faris Ã¾ou now, foull mott Ã¾e fall! iii Mil. Nowe be-cause he oure kyng gon hym call, We will kyndely hym croune with a brere. iv Mil. ?a, but first Ã¾is purpure and palle, And Ã¾is worthy wede sall he were for scorne. i Mil. I am prowd at Ã¾is poynte to appere. ii Mil. Latte vs clethe hym in Ã¾er clothes full clere, As a lorde Ã¾at his lordshippe has lorne. 34. iii Mil. Lange or Ã¾ou mete slike a men?e as Ã¾ou mett with Ã¾is morne! iv Mil. Do sette hym in Ã¾is sete, as a semely in sales. i Mil. Now thryng to hym thrally with Ã¾is Ã¾ikk Ã¾orne. ii Mil. Lo! it heldes to his hede, Ã¾at Ã¾e harnes out hales. iii Mil. Thus we teche hym to tempre his tales, His brayne begynnes for to blede. iv Mil. ?a, his blondre has hym broght to Ã¾er bales. Now reche hym and raught hym in a rede so rounde, For his septure it serues in dede. i Mil. ?a, it is gode i-nowe in Ã¾is nede, Late vs gudly hym grete on Ã¾is grounde. 35. Aue! riall roy and rex judeorum! Hayle! comely kyng, Ã¾at no kyngdom has kende, Hayll! vndughty duke, Ã¾i dedis ere dom, Hayll! man, vnmyghty Ã¾i men?e to mende. iii Mil. Hayll! lord with-out lande for to lende, Hayll! kyng, hayll! knave vnconand. iv Mil. Hayll! freyke, without forse Ã¾e to fende. Hayll! strang, Ã¾at may not wele stand To stryve. i Mil. We! harlott, heve vp thy hande, And vs all Ã¾at Ã¾e wirschip are wirkand Thanke vs, Ã¾er ill mot Ã¾ou Ã¾ryve. 36. ii Mil. So late lede hym be-lyve, and lenge her no lenger, To Sir Pilate oure prince our pride will we prayse. iii Mil. ?a, he may synge or he slepe of sorowe and angir, For many derfe dedes he has done in his dayes. iv Mil. Now wightly late wende on oure wayes, Late vs trusse vs, no tyme is to tarie. [They go to Pilate. i Mil. My lorde, will ?e listen oure layes? Here Ã¾is boy is, ?e bade vs go bary With battis. ii Mil. We ar combered his corpus for to cary, Many wightis on hym wondres and wary; Lo! his flesh al be be-flapped Ã¾at fat is. 37. Pil. Wele, bringe hym be-fore vs; [They do so.] A! he blisshes all bloo, I suppose of his seggyng he will cese euermore. Sirs, be-holde vpon hight and ecce homoo, Ãus bounden and bette and broght you be-fore. Me semes Ã¾at it sewes hym full sore. For his gilte on this grounde is he greuyd, If ?ou like for to listen my lore, In race. 38. [Pil.] For propirly by Ã¾is processe will I preve I had no force fro Ã¾Ã­s felawshippe Ã¾is freke for to lende. Preco. Here is all, sir, Ã¾at ?e for sende, Will ?e wasshe whill Ã¾e watir is hote? [Barabbas is brought in. Pil. Nowe Ã¾is Barabas bandes ?e vnbende, With grace late hym gange on his gate Where ?e will. Bar. ?e worthy men, Ã¾at I here wate, God encrece all youre comely estate, For Ã¾e grace ?e haue graunt me vn-till. 39. Pil. Here Ã¾e jugement of Jesu, all Jewes in Ã¾is stede, Crucifie hym on a crosse and on Caluerye hym kill, I dampne hym to-day to dy Ã¾is same dede, Ãerfore hyngis hym on hight vppon Ã¾at high hill. And on aythir side hym I will, Ãat a harlott ?e hyng in Ã¾is hast, Me thynkith it both reasoune and skill Emyddis, sen his malice is mast, ?e hyng hym. Ãen hym turmente, som tene for to tast; Mo wordis I will not nowe wast, But blynne not to dede to ?e bryng hym. 40. Cay. Sir, vs semys in oure sight Ã¾at ?e sadly has saide, Now knyghtis Ã¾at are conant with Ã¾is catyf ?e care, The liffe of Ã¾is losell in youre list is it laide. i Mil. Late vs alone, my lorde, and lere vs na lare. Siris, sette to hym sadly and sare, All in cordis his coorse vmbycast. ii Mil. Late vs bynde hym in bandis all bare, iii Mil. Here is one, full lange will it laste. iv Mil. Lay on hande here. v Mil. I powll to my poure is past. Nowe feste is he, felawes, ful fast, Late vs stere vs, we may not long stand here. 41. An. Drawe hym faste, hense delyuere ?ou, haue done. Go, do se hym to dede withoute lenger delay. For dede bus hym be nedlyng be none.
